description: Number of permutations of digits of n which denote primes.
comments: Consider all k! permutations of digits of a k-digit number n, discard initial zeros, count distinct primes.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
example: a(20)=1, since from {02, 20} we get {2,20} and only 2 is prime. From 107 we get 4 primes: (0)17, (0)71, 107 and 701; so a(107) = 4.
prog: (PARI) for(x=1, 400, print1(permprime(x), ",")) /* for definition of function permprime cf. link */ [From _Cino Hilliard_, Jun 07 2009](MAGMA) [ #[ s: s in Seqset([ Seqint([m(p[i]):i in [1..#x] ], 10): p in Permutations(Seqset(x)) ]) | IsPrime(s) ] where m is map< x->y | [<x[i],y[i]>:i in [1..#x] ] > where x is [1..#y] where y is Intseq(n,10): n in [1..120] ]; [From _Klaus Brockhaus_, Jun 15 2009](Haskell)import Data.List (permutations, nub)a039999 n = length $ filter ((== 1) . a010051)                   (map read (nub $ permutations $ show n) :: [Integer])-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Feb 07 2011
author: _David W. Wilson_
extensions: Contribution of _Cino Hilliard_ edited by _Klaus Brockhaus_, Jun 15 2009
